thread.title: Stock Futures Rebound as Private Payroll Growth Slows
thread.title_full: Stock Futures Rebound as Private Payroll Growth Slows

title: Stock Futures Rebound as Private Payroll Growth Slows
text:
Reprint 
NEW YORK ( TheStreet ) -- Stock futures were setting markets up for a rebound on Wednesday after three days in the red. 
S&P 500 futures were up 0.68%, Dow Jones Industrial Average futures added 0.45%, and Nasdaq futures gained 0.72%. 
The U.S. trade deficit increased 7.1% to $43.84 billion in June, tied to a higher volume of auto imports from Europe, according to the Commerce Department on Wednesday. Economists had expected the deficit to climb to $42.8 billion from a revised $40.9 billion in May. 
The private sector added 185,000 jobs in July, according to the ADP Private Jobs report. The reading was well below an expected 210,000 increase over the month. June's report was revised down to 229,000 from 8,000. 
Must Read: Warren Buffett's Top 10 Dividend Stocks 
Though its track record has been spotty, the ADP report is used as a litmus test for the labor market ahead of the official monthly jobs report. The July employment situation report from the Labor Department is out this Friday and economists expect nonfarm payrolls to increase 212,000 after a 223,000 jump in June. 
Investors have been on high alert for signs of weakness in economic data ahead of the next Federal Reserve meeting in September. Economists widely expect the Fed to raise rates at that meeting, which would be the Fed's first money-tightening policy action in nine years. 
Dreamworks ( DWA - Get Report ) shares were on watch after the animation studio reported a net loss of 13 cents a share, half the loss analysts expected. Revenue jumped 40% to $170.78 million and beat estimates by just over $4 million. 
Disney ( DIS - Get Report ) fell more than 2% in premarket trading after missing sales estimates in its third quarter. Revenue of $13.1 billion missed expectations by $130 million. Profits were better than expected, though, climbing 11% and exceeding forecasts for the 11th consecutive quarter. 
Time Warner ( TWX - Get Report ) earned $1.25 a share in its recent quarter, 22 cents above estimates. Quarterly sales of $7.34 billion increased 8% from a year earlier and beat expectations by $440 million. The entertainment conglomerate saw its strongest growth at Warner Bros., tied to the strong video game releases of Batman: Arkham Knight and Mortal Kombat X . 
Priceline ( PCLN ) jumped more than 9% in premarket trading after soaring past quarterly estimates. The online travel agency earned $12.45 a share, 47 cents above estimates. Revenue fell short, though, with sales of $1.28 billion down 40% from a year earlier and coming in $990 million shy of expectations. 
Wall Street ripped from deep to shallow losses on Tuesday as volatility returned to markets ahead of Friday's jobs report. The session marked the third day in the red, though benchmark indexes' losses were mild. Check Out Our Best Services for Investors 
Portfolio Manager Jim Cramer and Director of Research Jack Mohr reveal their investment tactics while giving advanced notice before every trade. Product Features:
